# Is excluding false beliefs sufficient for defining knowledge?

**Node Type:** antithesis
**Node ID:** c5bee0c9-dc47-495b-9b2e-9ede050759ba
**Depth:** 4
**Terminal:** No

**Parent:** [Reliabilism as a Knowledge Theory](reliabilism-as-a-knowledge-theory-synthesis-b5bdc6be-6410-4aae-a2f1-e20391888e99.md)

## Content

**Consider a scenario in which a belief formed by a reliable process is true but surrounded by a set of other false beliefs generated by similar processes. Intuitively, the presence of false beliefs complicates the attribution of knowledge to the true one.**, **There is a plausible principle indicating that the exclusive formation of true beliefs strengthens the case for knowledge.**
